entries.content: Ask for permission at the start with a time limit: 'Can I have 30 seconds tell me what you're up to see if there's a fit?'
Set expectation early to reduce pressure: 'If by the end of this short chat here you don't think I can help you, you promise to hang up, right?'
Address likely objections directly with a question: 'Sounds like you're not interested, is that right?'
Rephrase 'not interested' objection to focus on lack of change needed: 'Sounds like you're not looking to make any changes right now.'
Reframe 'not interested' as 'Is it just not a fit for what you're doing?'
Grant permission for the prospect to disengage at any time: 'You can tell me no at any time...'
Check for agreement or permission before proceeding: 'Is that fair?'
Ask about the current process to understand the status quo: 'So tell me a little bit about like what happens today?'
Uncover pain by asking about consequences of inaction: 'What happens if you don't do this?'
Uncover gain by asking about desired positive outcomes: 'What would it mean to you if you could actually achieve this?'
Identify pain points by asking about challenges: 'What's been the biggest challenge around this?'

Handle 'not interested' by offering polite alternative reasons and asking which one: '...typically when I hear someone say that it's one of two things: either I caught you at a bad time... or potentially maybe what I said just doesn't resonate... which one is it?'
entries.notes: Offer two polite reasons for objection and ask prospect to pick.

entries.content: Handle 'send me information' by asking what specific info is needed based on the conversation: 'I'm happy to send you information... what kind of information would be most helpful for you right now based on our conversation?'

Handle 'send me information' by qualifying the request to avoid useless documents: '...just so I make sure I don't send you like a 40 page document... what specifically were you hoping to learn or see from the information?'

Handle 'send me information' by offering two direct reasons for the request (genuine vs. brush-off) and asking which one: '...typically when someone asks for information it's usually one of two things: either they're legitimately interested... or it's just a polite way of getting me off the phone... which one is it?'
entries.notes: Offer two direct reasons for info request (genuine vs. brush-off) and ask prospect to pick.

entries.content: Handle 'send me information' by asking about the next step after review: '...what would be the next step after you review that information?'
Qualify the decision process when info is requested: 'Like what's going to be the decision process?'
Qualify who is involved in the decision when info is requested: 'who else is involved in this decision?'
Qualify the timeline for decision when info is requested: 'When do you typically make a decision on something like this?'
Qualify the budget when info is requested: 'What's the budget for this?'
